steps.text: Dr.Sweeney is creating a sapient creature in his laboratory.
Help him build a circulatory system to transport oxygen and nutrients to different parts of the sapient creature’s body.

question.text: Add a blood vessel to carry the deoxygenated blood from the lower parts of the body to the heart.

feedBack.text: Yes! Inferior vena cava collects the deoxygenated blood from the lower parts of the body to the heart.
Oops! Superior vena cava does not collect deoxygenated blood from the lower parts of the body.

question.text: Add a blood vessel to carry the deoxygenated blood from the upper parts of the body to the heart.

feedBack.text: Yes! Superior vena cava collects the deoxygenated blood from the upper parts of the body to the heart.
Oops! The artery does not collect the deoxygenated blood from different parts of the body.

question.text: Now, add the correct heart chamber to receive this deoxygenated blood flowing at low pressure.

feedBack.text: Correct! The thin muscular walled right atrium will be suitable to receive deoxygenated blood entering at low pressure.
The chamber needs to receive the blood flowing at low pressure the right ventricle with the thick muscular wall is not suitable.

question.text: Add the correct heart chamber to pump the deoxygenated blood flowing at high pressure to the lungs for oxygenation.

feedBack.text: Yes! The right ventricle pumps the deoxygenated blood to the lungs for oxygenation.
The thick muscular wall of the right ventricle will help to withstand the high pressure required to pump the blood to the lungs.
Uh-oh! The left atrium only receives deoxygenated blood and is made up of a thin muscular wall.
It cannot withstand the pressure produced while pumping the blood.

question.text: Add the correct blood vessel to carry the deoxygenated blood that is pumped at high pressure to the lungs.

feedBack.text: Yes! The pulmonary artery carries the deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs for oxygenation.
It can withstand the blood flowing at high pressure because of its thick and elastic walls.
Nope! The vein cannot carry the deoxygenated blood flowing at high pressure.It might break due to its thin-walled structure.

question.text: Add the correct blood vessel to carry the oxygenated blood back to the heart from the lungs, at low pressure.

feedBack.text: Yup! The pulmonary vein carries the oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart.
Since the oxygenated blood flows with low pressure, the blood vessel with a thin wall is most suitable to carry the blood back to the heart.
Oops! The thick-walled artery is not required, since blood flows at lower pressure.

question.text: Add the correct heart chamber to receive the oxygenated blood back to the heart flowing at low pressure.

feedBack.text: Correct! The left atrium receives oxygenated blood from the lungs.
The left atrium with the thin and weak muscular wall is suitable since blood comes in at low pressure.
Uh-no! The chamber needs to receive the oxygenated blood coming at low pressure; the left ventricle with the thick muscular wall not required.

question.text: Add the correct heart chamber to recieve the oxygenated blood back to the heart flowing at low pressure.

feedBack.text: Yes! The left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood to various parts of the body.
The thick and strong muscular wall of the right ventricle will help to withstand the high pressure required to pump the blood to the different body parts.
Uh-oh! The right atrium only receives deoxygenated blood, adding it here won’t help pump the oxygenated blood to the different parts of the body.
Also, It is thin-walled and not suitable here.

question.text: Add the correct blood vessel to carry oxygenated blood from the left ventricle at high pressure to different body parts.

feedBack.text: Yes! The aorta is the largest artery that carries blood from the left ventricle to different parts of the body.
It can withstand the blood flowing at high pressure because of its thick and elastic layer.
Uh-oh! Due to the thin nature of its walls, the vein is not suitable to pump oxygenated blood to different body parts.
Vein with valves is not required since blood is already at high pressure.

question.text: Now, add the correct blood vessel to exchange the nutrients and gases between blood and tissues in the body.

feedBack.text: Yes! Capillaries help in the exchange of gases and the diffusion of nutrients into the tissues.
It is possible due to the thinness of its walls.
Uh-oh! The artery cannot effectively exchange nutrients and gases across tissues because its walls are too thick.
Vein with valves is not required since blood is already at high pressure.

steps.text: Good job! You have successfully completed building the entire circulatory system for the sapient creature.
